definitions.definition: having a larger distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal

examples.text: a thick slice of bread
a thick book *(= one that has a lot of pages)*
a thick coat *(= one made of heavy cloth)*
thick fingers
Everything was covered with a thick layer of dust.
Use fairly thick wads of newspaper.
He wore thick glasses.
a thick carpet of snow

definitions.definition: used to ask about or state the distance between opposite sides or surfaces

examples.text: How thick are the walls?
They're two feet thick.
The silk thread is only slightly thicker than a hair.

definitions.definition: growing closely together in large amounts or numbers

examples.text: thick dark hair
This breed of cattle has a very thick coat.
His eyebrows were thick and bushy.
a thick forest
a screen of trees thick enough to conceal the building entirely
She padded noiselessly across the thick carpet (= that has a large number of fibres pressed closely together).
thick soup
The effect will be ruined if the paint is too thick.
I was buried up to my waist in thick mud, unable to move.

definitions.definition: difficult to see through; difficult to breathe in

examples.text: The plane crashed in thick fog.
Thick black smoke rose over the city.
Thick cloud covered the sky.
The air had grown thick and smoky.
The air was thick with dust.
The atmosphere was thick with tension.

definitions.definition: having a large number of people or a large amount of something in one place

examples.text: The beach was thick with sunbathers.

definitions.definition: an offensive way to describe somebody who is slow to learn or understand things

examples.text: I'm not completely thick, you know.

definitions.definition: easily recognized as being from a particular country or area

examples.text: a thick Brooklyn accent

definitions.definition: deep and not as clear as normal, especially because of illness or emotion

examples.text: His voice was thick with emotion.

definitions.definition: very friendly with somebody, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation

examples.text: You seem to be very thick with the boss!

definitions.definition: family relationships are stronger than any others
to hit somebody/be hit on the head as a punishment

examples.text: You’ll get a thick ear if you’re not careful!

definitions.definition: very friendly, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol

examples.text: You’re going to have a thick head in the morning!

definitions.definition: used to show that you are annoyed that somebody does not understand something

examples.text: When will you get it into your thick head that I don't want to see you again!

definitions.definition: if people or things are thick/thin on the ground, there are a lot/not many of them in a place

examples.text: Customers are thin on the ground at this time of year.
Security officers were thick on the ground during the King’s visit.

definitions.definition: the ability to accept criticism, offensive remarks, etc. without becoming upset

wordOrigin: Old English thicce, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dik and German dick.
